title: Fragments of cuneiform medicine in the Babylonian Talmud: Knowledge Transfer in Late Antiquity
descriptions: The "Fragments of cuneiform medicine in the Babylonian Talmud: Knowledge Transfer in Late Antiquity" project, known as BabMed, aims to conduct the first comprehensive study of ancient Babylonian medical science since the decipherment of cuneiform. Focusing on the latest phase of Babylonian medicine in the Babylonian Talmud, which is written in Aramaic, the project seeks to test hypotheses that suggest cuneiform survived longer than previously thought and that Aramaic medicine in the Babylonian Talmud largely stems from Akkadian medicine. By utilizing native taxonomies and comparing with neighboring medical systems, BabMed challenges the prevalent Eurocentric histories that often only compare to Greek medicine. The project aims to establish a new paradigm for understanding knowledge transfer by overcoming barriers such as script and language. With a unique text in the Babylonian Talmud and a geographical context spanning Greco-Roman Palestine and Persian Babylonia, BabMed is positioned to reveal how Babylonian medicine survived the transition from cuneiform to Aramaic script. This project represents a significant contribution to the understanding of ancient medical practices before Hippocrates, providing valuable insights into the scientific thinking of both worlds.

This research will provide valuable insights into the scientific thinking of Greco-Roman Palestine and Persian Babylonia, offering a unique perspective on medical knowledge dissemination before the time of Hippocrates.
